alert.note: Alert for Darlington; Florence (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wilmington (Northeastern South Carolina and Southeastern North Carolina - Wilmington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued September 01 at 4:17PM EDT until September 02 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North Carolina...South Carolina... Lumber River Near Lumberton affecting Robeson County. Waccamaw River At Conway affecting Horry County. Black Creek At Quinby affecting Darlington and Florence Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in North Carolina...South Carolina... Northeast Cape Fear River Near Burgaw affecting Pender County. Lumber River 1 SE Nichols affecting Dillon, Marion and Horry Counties. Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Marion and Horry Counties. Black River At Kingstree affecting Williamsburg County. For the Northeast Cape Fear River...including Burgaw...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Lumber River...including Nichols, Pembroke, Lumberton Usgs Gage, Maxton, Lumberton, Boardman...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Little Pee Dee River...including Galivants Ferry...Major flooding is forecast. For the Waccamaw River...including Aiw At old Hwy 544 At Socastee, Conway, Above Conway, Freeland, Longs...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Black Creek...including Black Creek Nr Hartsville, Quinby... Minor flooding is forecast. For the Black River...including Kingstree...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Black Creek at Quinby. * WHEN...Until tomorrow morning. * IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Flood stage. Creek coming out of its banks. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:00 PM EDT Friday the stage was 10.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage this evening and continue falling to 6.9 feet early Wednesday afternoon. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=ilm . The next statement will be issued by Saturday morning.
